p: The occurrence of HEV in urban wastewater raises the question of whether sewage-contaminated surface waters can be responsible for HEV waterborne transmission. A recent review by Fenaux et al. [ 67] highlighted the need to investigate the possible transmission of the hepatitis E virus by water in high-income countries. Indeed, HEV has been detected in different water matrices even in these countries; moreover, HEV survival in water is similar to other enteric viruses since it seems that the virus has similar resistance to inactivating factors like heat, UV, and chlorine [ 67]. In Italy, HEV has been recently detected in river waters receiving wastewater discharges [ 78]. Moreover, HEV strains have been isolated from shellfish, marine waters, and underwater sewage discharges [ 79, 80].
